speaker: Viral image
vclaim: President Trump is asking everyone to send this e-mail...
date: stated on September 26, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, Trump doesn't ask you to send an e-mail about the Tramp Rules.
text: Does President Donald Trump send a serial mail? Facebook says that "everyone is asked to send this e-mail." "In three days, most people in the United States will have this message," "This is an idea that must pass, regardless of the political party. Rules of the Federation: Congress Reform Act 2017 No term of employment/no pension. The woman congresswoman collects a salary while in office and does not receive a wage when she is outside her post. And no more benefits go with them." Other rules set out in the position include requiring Congressional representatives to participate in social security, to buy their own retirement plans and to buy health care through the same system as citizens. It also prohibits Congress from voting to increase the remuneration of representatives. This article, in which more than 75,000 people participated, was referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation in the broadcast of the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) Someone may be bothering you about this fake legislation, but he's not the president. Facebook was published on January 11, 2021 in the Nancy Belusi newspaper, no longer the Speaker of the House of Representatives by Samantha Buterman: January 12, 2021, almost identical versions of this article appeared on the Internet early in 2009. In that year Warren Buffett was supposed to ask people to send an e-mail about a proposed constitutional amendment to at least 20 people on their address list. In 2011, it was called the Congressional Reform Act of 2011, and Trump did not mention it. (Think about many of the allegations of the letter at that time and reconsider the subject again when it reappeared with the attached name of the Chairman.) In 2012, Warren Buffett was in it again! In 2018, the letter appeared as a petition for Congressional Reform Act 2018, which was posted on e-mail.com. And now, in 2019, we're here to say that if you deliver this reboot message, you'll have seven years of bad luck. We're assessing this Facebook mail pants on fire!
